results.notes: Growing on the underside of a chunk of decorticated Quercus wood with Hyphoderma argillaceum observation 322868. Monomitic with simple-septate generative hyphae. Basal hyphae smooth and up to 8.18 µm wide. Cystidia and hyphidia absent. Basidia 6-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (8.7) 9.4 – 15.4 (18.2) × (6.6) 7 – 9 (9.6) µm, Q = (1) 1.2 – 1.7 (2.3); N = 30, Me = 11.4 × 7.9 µm; Qe = 1.4. Spores smooth, hyaline, navicular and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (6.2) 6.3 – 8.8 (9) × (2.8) 2.9 – 3.7 (4) µm, Q = (1.9) 2 – 2.4 (2.5); N = 14, Me = 7.4 × 3.4 µm; Qe = 2.2.

results.notes:
Pileus: 5 cm wide, orangish with central depression. Cuticle peeling 1/3-1/2
Stipe: 4 cm long, 1.5 cm wide
Habitat: Found in mixed woods near pine and various hardwoods
Taste: Mild
The stipe context appeared to bruise very slight red/pink at first, then clearly gray after a couple hours. This appears to match the description of Russula decolorans, except for the very slight pinkish red bruising initially. Another option appears to be Russula claroflava, but again there is no mention of a red stage, and the description of that states that the pileus is almost always completely yellow. The Russulales news key also suggests Russula barlae, but I couldn’t find much information on that species.

results.notes:
Nearby Trees: Conifer, predominately Douglas Fir and Hemlock
Substrate: Dead Wood Pieces, Dense Humus Soil, Needle Duff
Habit: One to Three
Odor: Musky at first, turning fetid during aging/drying process
Taste: Pleasant, Nutty

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

Cap: Hemispheric, smooth, initially Bright Yellow, ~2.5” wide. Flesh is white, thick, very firm, and turning light-to-medium brown where cut or bruised. Somewhat viscid/tacky when wet. Distinct, regular, sharp edges. Forest duff almost “glued” to top, and difficult to remove. Cap dries to a mottled medium brown.

Gills: White, adnexed, crowded, but equally spaced. Light-to-medium brown where cut or bruised. Gills dry to a grayish-brown.

Stipe: White, clavate, central attachment, smooth w/very fine and closely spaced vertically running ridges, ~1.5” long. Light-to-medium brown where cut or bruised. Stipe dries to an off-white with splotches of pale gray-brown.

Spores: White

Mycelia: White, very dense, directly below the forest duff. Appears to run shallow in the packed substrate, ~ ½”

notes_fields.Substrate: Subduff decayed plant matter or living stem or root matter

results.notes:
I discovered these tiny orange structures when I was digging underneath of the leaf litter to excavate an Amanita. The structures were bright orange when fresh, drying to a darker red and very hard. They were very abundant in one patch, growing on decayed twigs and leaves, but also, to my surprise, growing on the stem/root of a living herbaceous plant. The reproductive structures were not delicate themselves, but their attachment to the substrate was, falling off very easily. They were attached to the substrate via a thin white mat that was reminiscent of stretched white adhesive putty or tack.
Microscopically, I did not observe any hyphae or sexual reproductive structures. The organism was composed of a neon yellow nucleus surrounded by large globose cells. The yellow nucleus also seemed to be composed of globose cells, but they were difficult to distinguish. Throughout many small oil droplets were visible.
Carlos Rojas from the University of Costa Rica confirmed that these are Myxomycete sclerotia, unidentifiable without DNA or culture studies.

—

results.notes:
Nearby Trees: Conifer, predominately Douglas Fir and Hemlock
Substrate: Thick Moss, Dense Humus Soil, Sand
Habit: Two in close proximity
Odor: Musty
Taste: unknown…flesh is too fibrous

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

Cap: Irregularly shaped, rounded rectangle, smooth, velvety, initially bright cream-white, but turning very-pale grey with very-pale light blue around the rounded edges 24 hours after removal from forest. Dimensions: from the top: ~2-3” long & 1-1.5” wide. AFTER CUTTING: The flesh is two-layered…a spongy, white thin line at top, turning a light, rusty orange further down. This latter area is thick, cork-like, and has vertically oriented cleavages within the flesh, giving an appearance of closely packed human-teeth. The flesh along the cleavages are a cream-white. AFTER WETTING: The top changes to a darker grey with dark brown, worm-shaped runners. The cleavages turn a dark cerulean blue. The rest of the flesh becomes a darker rust-brown. (NOTE: It would appear these cleavages may represent individual fruit bodies which have fused, forming a larger specimen. This would also help to explain the irregular shape of the cap).

Spines: Very thin, ~1-3mm long, very close, crowded with some overlapping. Spines near the cap top are more like “nubs”, whereas the ones furthest down are the longest. The thicker part of the spine is attached to the flesh (cap & stipe), tapering to a sharp point. Color is off-white along the spine surface, and pale grey (perhaps blue) along the sides. The spines cease near the base of the stipe, roughly even with the area covered by the thickest moss.

Stipe: ~1-2” long, tapered, somewhat eccentric, shape conforms roughly to that of the cap. It is covered with spines of varying lengths and thickness. Flesh is two-layered. Outer layer: thin and buff-colored. Inner area: Predominant color is rusty brown, getting darker towards the stipe end. Bottom ½ – ¾ inches: The flesh is very-thick and wood-like with no spines attached.

Spores: According to ref material it should be brownish

Mycelia: Light Orange to yellow, thread-like…more like plant roots. Appears to run directly below and within the moss roots.

results.notes: This species “fruits” or I should say re-constitutes throughout the year and can be viewed in pretty much every location in lowland Western Washington State. The mycelium is extremely tenuous and very aggressive(pulling up fruiting body will usually bring along a huge mat of leaf and needle debris). Stems turn yellow with drying, and stem base of fresh fruiting bodies is always “woolly”, hence the common name of wood woolly foot.

Parasitizing Western Hemlock.

I inoculated this large Western hemlock log many years ago and have been posting and noting fruiting each season. Interestingly this substrate was already inhabited by G. applanatum and F. tsugina when I first inoculated it with fresh stem butts harvested in the Northern Olympic peninsula. All three species are slowly but surely breaking down the lignin material which will eventually be broken down back into usable soil. See final image I added of a fresh Hemlock next to a nearly fully broken down section of the log for example of cubicle rot and what Saprophytes do to recycle material back into usable material for the ecosystem.

results.notes:
Very old, dry and maggot riddled collection(“cornbread status” as I like to call them) fruiting within feet of abundant flowering of Inidan Pipe(Monotropa uniflora) a parasitic(Mycoheterotrophic flowering) plant that lives off of R. brevipes mycelium(does not grow via photosynthesis-as with all Mycoheterotroph’s).

R. brevipes is edible but bland. However, it is one of H. lactifluorum’s favorite species to parasitize and convert into what is known as “lobster mushrooms.” Interestingly enough I collected a decent harvest of fresh H. lactifluorum a few yards away and have collected in this area for a decade. Long story short… R. brevipes are a good indicator for the possibility of lobster mushrooms in the given canopy. Furthermore, Indian pipe(M. uniflora) area great indicator for finding R. brevipes. Basic formula for success- If you see indian pipe, it is possible you will most likely find lobster mushrooms some time of the year in that canopy. This method of memorizing indicators of both plants and associated fungi is the best way to have successful harvests and observations of a vast number of species of fungi, plants and critters each and every season.

results.notes:
Found very close to a small fruiting of Russula brevipes and flowering of Monotropa uniflora(Indian pipe). All are indicators for one another as H. lactifluorum favors parasitizing R. brevipes and R. brevipes is the favorite nutrient source for Monotropa uniflora. I have monitored and successfully used this method for these and many other species and associations in a similar fashion for more than a decade.

results.notes:
Growing in mixed birch/oak forest. Cap: 7.5-10 cm, dry, mottled light yellowish brown. Young caps the same color. Doesn’t bruise upon handling or bruises only slightly brownish. Cap flesh pale yellow, bruises pale blue upon cutting.
Tubes about 1 cm deep, depressed at the stipe apex, yellow, staining pale blue. Pores 2-3/mm, dark golden brown, stain almost black when bruised. Stipe: 2-3 cm thick x 11-12 cm long. One specimen equal, the other tapering to the base. Yellow when young, maturing to yellow at the apex and lighter below with darker streaks and flecks. Doesn’t seem to bruise on the outside. Stipe flesh whitish to very pale yellow with reddish streaks, bruising slightly blue only at the apex upon cutting. Base of stipe dark reddish purple inside. Stipe flesh riddled with worm holes, stained dark brown. Ammonia on cap: briefly blue then purple, pale orange on flesh. KOH: orange on cap, pale orange on flesh. Iron salts: greenish on cap, negative on flesh. Spores inamyloid, subfusiform to elliptical, (8)8.7-12.2(12.7) x 3-3.7(4.3), mean = 10.1 (SD 1.1) x 3.4 (SD 0.3), n=42. Note that spores were measured from a tissue sample; I couldn’t get a spore print. Dried specimens not particularly malodorous.

results.notes: Growing in well-rotted mixture of donkey and alpaca manure. Caps cream to tan colored, conical, 1-2.5 cm dia. Thin brownish flesh. Spores elliptic with an obvious apical germ pore, smooth, brown in water, thick walls, (13.6)14-15.7(15.9) x (7.6)7.7-8.9(9). Mean = 14.8 (SD 0.6) x 8.3 (SD 0.4), n=30. Basidia bisterigmate. results.notes:
Four small fruiting bodies growing near a trail in the vicinity of mature red oaks. Other trees nearby are maple, sweet gum and flowering cherry. This species was found at exactly the same location two years ago, obs 244045.
The largest basidicarp was infected with hypomyces and was not collected. The second largest fb had a 3.7 cm wide cap and a ~4 cm long stipe. Medium brown to dark chocolate brown caps bruising blue; medium lemon yellow pores immediately staining dark blue; equal stipes with brilliant lemon-yellow apices, also yellow below but covered with reddish and brown stains; the flesh is bright yellow in the stipe and paler yellow in the cap, instantly staining blue in the cap and upper stipe, darker blue and reddish-brown in stipe base; odor slightly pungent, a bit perfumed. KOH = blackish cherry-red on cap cuticle and brownish-orange on cap context.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 25-Apr-20):
A partial nrITS sequence was derived from this material by Dr. Kudzma from a single (forward) read. It consists of the first 287 bps of the locus covering the entire ITS1 and partial 5.8S regions. There are no ambiguities.
A BLASTn of this sequence indicates this collection is not conspecific with the true European C. pulverulentus — see the attached phylo tree.

results.notes: Mild taste, indistinct scent; caps range between about 7 cm and 12 cm. Gills are cream, with frequent forking near the stipe and also right at the margin; occasional sub-gills are present. Stipe is usually light brown, but can range between white and gray-brown on different individuals. Mass spore color is white to cream; spore length: 6.8-7.8(8.2), width: (5.7)5.9-6.7(7.0) (n=20); maximum wart height averages about 0.16 microns, warts are incompletely connected (Woo B1-C1) (stained with IKI, not Melzer’s). The flesh does not discolor when cut. I’ve found this species in three widely separated locations in the region in June and July, always among Sitka Spruce (with or without hemlock and grand fir; hardwoods have rarely been present in the vicinity). The observed characteristics are consistent with those for R. brunneola as described by Thiers (1997) and by Roberts (2007; Russulas of Southern Vancouver Island Coastal Forests). Judging from the description, this is the same species observed in the same area by Peter Werner (Observation 244695) on 7/12/2016.

results.notes: I am not sure if these are Devil’s Cigars (Texas stars) or not. But I couldn’t find any other that seemed to match other photos and descriptions. I use wood mulch year after year. I found these underneath my dense Latham Raspberry bushes that overgrew perennial flowers I planted last year (mums, black eyed susans) from a commercial garden center (Menards). We have had a very hot spring and recently a lot of rain. The ground was where a maple tree had been cut down 5 years ago, mulched with 10 years of wood mulch. There was not much air movement possible as the raspberry branches reached the ground. Some of the mushrooms emerged from underneath a board I had left on the ground last sumer, and some of the mushrooms grew in a half circle around the base of the perennial flower I planted.
